head.title: A Gathering of New Isms, Old Masters and Noodles

hedline.hl1: A Gathering of New Isms, Old Masters and Noodles

abstract.p: Annotated list of art exhibits set to open this fall; photos (L)

block.p: A * indicates an event of special note.
September

* ''SOL LEWITT: A RETROSPECTIVE'' Mr. LeWitt, a linchpin figure between Minimalism and Conceptualism, is celebrated in a retrospective that ranges from early, spare text pieces to modular sculptures to the colorful wall drawings he has been masterminding in recent years. The show is at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, through Oct. 22. It travels to the Whitney Museum of American Art. Dec. 7-Feb. 25. Mr. LeWitt's work from the 1970's is on view in a small show titled ''Incomplete Open Cubes'' at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. Jan. 27-April 29.
A * indicates an event of special note.
September

* ''SOL LEWITT: A RETROSPECTIVE'' Mr. LeWitt, a linchpin figure between Minimalism and Conceptualism, is celebrated in a retrospective that ranges from early, spare text pieces to modular sculptures to the colorful wall drawings he has been masterminding in recent years. The show is at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, through Oct. 22. It travels to the Whitney Museum of American Art. Dec. 7-Feb. 25. Mr. LeWitt's work from the 1970's is on view in a small show titled ''Incomplete Open Cubes'' at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. Jan. 27-April 29.

''TOM FRIEDMAN'' From mundane materials -- ballpoint pens, chewing gum, aspirins -- this young artist makes labor-intensive art of immense wit and ingenuity. A one-decade survey, organized by the Southeastern Center for Contemporary Art (Secca) in Winston-Salem, N.C., is on view at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago through Oct 1, then moves on to the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, San Francisco (Nov. 4-Jan. 28); Aspen Art Museum. Colorado (Feb. 16-April 15); Secca (July 14-Sept. 24); and the New Museum of Contemporary Art, N.Y. (Oct. 11-Jan. 17, 2002)

''PARADISE NOW'' The new season's first entry in the Big Science sweepstakes. Genetic engineering is the theme tackled by the curators Carole Kismaric and Marvin Heiferman, with the artists Julian LaVerdiere, Inigo Manglano-Ovalle, Alexis Rockman, Mark Dion and others. Exit Art. Through Oct. 28. (212-966-7745) www.exitart.org.

''THE NEW FRONTIER: ART AND TELEVISION, 1960-1965'' Organized by the art historian John Alan Farmer, the show considers the influence of the Tube on the visual arts at a formative moment in American culture. Among the members of the TV generation to be included: Wallace Berman, Bruce Conner, Yoko Ono, Nam June Paik and Andy Warhol. Austin Museum of Art. Through Nov. 26. (512-495-9224) www.amoa.org.

''JEREMY BLAKE'' This artist's use of dissolving photo projections to create the equivalent of geometric abstract paintings has been much admired of late. Four of his video projections, along with large-scale photographs, are on view at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, Philadelphia. Through Nov. 5.

''A BRUSH WITH NATURE: THE GERE COLLECTION OF LANDSCAPE OIL SKETCHES'' Arriving from the National Gallery, London, is a selection of modest-size 18th- and 19th-century landscape oil sketches, dashed off outdoors in an attempt to capture effects of light and atmosphere for reference in the studio. The Frick Collection. Tuesday through Nov. 12.

''JORGE PARDO: PROJECT'' Mr. Pardo's art-and-function project entails redesigning the lobby of the Dia Center's building in Chelsea, staging an exhibition in a reconfigured gallery and creating a new bookstore on the premises. Dia Center for the Arts. Wednesday through June 17.

''THE CHINESE PAINTER AS POET'' presents an array of fans, hanging scrolls, wood-block prints and jade carvings, from the Song Dynasty to the 20th century, to trace the integration of the written word -- often poetry -- with the image in Chinese art. China Institute. Thursday through Dec. 10. (212-744-8181) www.chinainstitute.org.

* ''THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION'' The Chinese consider calligraphy their supreme cultural achievement, which is saying a lot. This show, made up of selections from some extraordinary American collections, is the largest survey of its kind ever mounted in the West. Metropolitan Museum of Art. Friday through Jan. 7.

''EAST OF THE RIVER: CHICANO ART COLLECTORS ANONYMOUS'' A show drawn from work owned by a group of private collectors who support and preserve the community-based work of Chicano artists in Los Angeles. Santa Monica Museum of Art. Friday through Nov. 18. (310-586-6488) www.netvip.com/smmoa.

''PIERRE AND GILLES'' Using make-up, costumes and lighting, this collaborative team creates fantasy photographs that are further glamorized through hand-painting. The end product: transcendental kitsch. New Museum of Contemporary Art. Friday through Jan. 21. A related article is on Page 91.

''UDOMSAK KRISANAMIS'' This young Thai artist uses materials like noodles and newspapers to create abstract works with relief surfaces and cosmological imagery. Wexner Center for the Arts, Columbus, Ohio. Saturday through December. (614-292-0330)www.wexarts.org.

''RONI HORN: STILL WATER (THE RIVER THAMES, FOR EXAMPLE), 1999'' An installation of 15 photographs of the surface of the Thames, each annotated by a text. The Whitney Museum of American Art. Saturday through Jan. 14.

''JOHN WESLEY: PAINTINGS 1961-2000'' A first United States retrospective for a maverick artist, born in Los Angeles in 1928, who paints animals, show girls and athletes in a distinctive cartoonlike style influenced by Matisse, Art Nouveau and Surrealism. Alanna Heiss does the curatorial honors. P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, Long Island City, Queens. Next Sunday through Jan. 15. (718-784-2084) www.ps1.org.

''FOUNTAINS OF LIGHT: ISLAMIC METALWORK FROM THE NUHAD ES-SAID COLLECTION'' More than two dozen inlaid precious-metal objects from present day Iran, Syria, Afghanistan and Turkey. Dating from the 10th to the 19th century, they're on long-term loan to the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery in Washington. Opens next Sunday.

''ART AND THE EMPIRE CITY: NEW YORK 1825-1861'' Between the year the Erie Canal was built and the beginning of the Civil War, New York turned into a commercial and cultural center and the largest city in the Western Hemisphere. This selection of 300 objects -- paintings, photography, furniture, silver -- documents the polishing of the Big Apple. Metropolitan Museum. Sept. 19-Jan. 7.

''AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE: ALEXANDRA EXTER, NATALIA GONCHAROVA, LIUBOV POPOVA, OLGA ROZANOVA, VARVARA STEPANOVA AND NADEZHDA UDALTSOVA'' Art by six Russian women who, in the first quarter of the 20th century, made significant contributions to the development of European modernism. Guggenheim Museum. Sept. 20-Jan. 7.

''FOCUS: STAN DOUGLAS'' Organized by Okwui Enwezor, this exhibition by a widely exhibited Canadian artist will include 25 large-format color photographs of the socially and economically battered city of Detroit and a documentary film with a hip-hop score. Art Institute of Chicago. Sept. 20-Dec. 19. (312-443-3600) www.artic.edu. A show of Mr. Douglas's photographs and videos will be at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles. Dec. 10-April 1.

''CY TWOMBLY: THE SCULPTURE'' includes 65 pieces in plaster, stone and bronze from 1946-98 by an artist best known for his abstract paintings. The show, which had its debut at the Kunstmuseum Basel, appears at the Menil Collection, Houston. Sept. 20-Jan. 7. (713-525-9400) www.menil.org. Traveling to the National Gallery of Art, Washington. May 6-July 29.

''BRIDGET RILEY: RECONNAISSANCE'' This British artist's optically mesmerizing paintings from the 1960's have long enjoyed mythic status, but are more often heard about than seen in New York. The exhibition will offer both older pieces and a new wall drawing. Dia Center for the Arts. Sept. 21-June 17.

''HIP-HOP NATION: ROOTS, RHYMES AND RAGE'' mixes video, music, art and fashion to examine an electrifying pop-cultural phenomenon, now two decades old, which has moved from the urban underground to television advertising. Brooklyn Museum of Art. Sept. 22-Dec. 31

''REMBRANDT CREATES REMBRANDT: ART AND AMBITION IN LEIDEN 1629-1631'' Rembrandt was a shrewd combination of soulfulness and showmanship. This small show focuses on his formative years and centers around an early self-portrait in the museum's collection. Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, Boston. Sept. 23-Jan. 7. (617-566-1401)www. boston.com/gardner.

* ''ULTRABAROQUE: ASPECTS OF POST-LATIN AMERICAN ART'' This traveling exhibition brings together 16 young artists from Latin America who examine the notion of a baroque sensibility long associated with Latin American art itself, but place this aesthetic in a context of international styles and loosened-up notions of cultural identity. The show opens at the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego at La Jolla. Sept. 23-Jan. 24. (858-454-3541) www.mcasandiego.org. Traveling to the Modern Art Museum, Fort Worth (Feb. 4-May 6); San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (Aug. 18-Jan. 2, 2002); Art Museum of Ontario, Toronto (Jan. 30-April 28, 2002); Miami Art Museum (June 20-Aug. 24, 2002); and the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis (Oct. 13, 2002-Jan. 5, 2003).

''LOUISE DAHL-WOLFE: THE AMERICA IMAGE'' A survey of more than 130 photographs, with clips and memorabilia, by a leading American fashion photographer, active from the 1930's to the 1960's and associated primarily with Harper's Bazaar. Center for Creative Photography, Tucson. Sept. 23-Nov. 26. (520-621-7968) www.creativephotography.org.

''WAYNE THIEBAUD: A PAINTINGS RETROSPECTIVE'' An 80th-birthday homage to a painterly California Pop artist who seems to be the latest inductee into the American Master Hall of Fame. Organized by the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, it will be at the Modern Art Museum Fort Worth Sept. 24-Jan. 14. (817-738-9215) www.mamfw.org. Traveling to the Phillips Collection, Washington (Feb. 10-April 29) and the Whitney Museum (June 28-Sept. 23). A show of the artist's prints will be at the Corcoran Gallery of Art. Feb. 3-April 22.
''MOROCCO: JEWS AND ART IN A MUSLIM LAND'' Jewish culture, an important

presence in North Africa, will be viewed through more than 180 objects, including gold and silver ceremonial objects, jewelry, textiles and Orientalist paintings of Eugene Delacroix. Jewish Museum. Sept. 24-Feb. 11.

''THE FILM ART OF ISAAC JULIEN'' Four multiscreen video installations, with photographs, make up a first solo museum show for an important black British independent filmmaker, best known for his sexy, dreamlike documentary film about the poet Langston Hughes, ''Looking for Langston'' (1989). Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. Sept. 24-Dec. 15. (845-758-7598) www.bard.edu.

''IN THE PRESENCE OF SPIRITS: SELECTIONS FROM THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF ETHNOLOGY, LISBON'' The show will include combs, carved pipes, stone funerary figures and monumental masks from Angola, Guinea and Ivory Coast, some making their first appearance in the United States. The show opens at the Museum for African Art. Sept. 27-Dec 31. (212-966-1313) www.africanart.org. Traveling to Flint Institute of Arts, Michigan (Feb. 1-April 29); National Museum of African Art, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, (June 10-Sept. 14); and the Birmingham Museum of Art, Alabama (Oct. 25, 2001-Jan. 5, 2002).

''RUSKIN'S ITALY, RUSKIN'S ENGLAND'' The Victorian monument named John Ruskin died 100 years ago, and this selection of drawings, watercolors, manuscripts, letters and artifacts, all from the Morgan Library's premier Ruskin holdings, offers a chance to pay tribute to his achievements and to ponder his elusive, unstable personality. Morgan Library. Sept. 28-Jan. 7.

* ''MOMA2000: OPEN ENDS'' The final lap of the Museum of Modern Art's millennial marathon of self-examination and, one hopes, self-renewal, will arrive in three sections with staggered opening dates. Together they will embrace work in the museum's collection from 1960 through the present, from Jasper Johns to Pipilotti Rist. Part I, Sept. 28-Jan. 2; Part II, Oct. 19-Jan. 30; Part III, Nov. 5-Jan. 30.
October

''A SPIRITUAL JOURNEY: THE ART OF EDDIE LEE KENDRICK'' A survey of paintings by an American self-taught artist who took his themes from the Bible, gospel hymns and dreams. His work was first noticed in 1977 when a teacher in a Little Rock, Ark., public elementary school, where Kendrick was a janitor, saw some of his paintings in the custodian's office. Fenimore Art Museum, Cooperstown, N.Y. Oct. 1-Dec. 31. (607-547-1400) www.fenimoreartmuseum.org.

''THE YEAR ONE: ART OF THE ANCIENT WORLD EAST AND WEST'' The Met gets into the millennium swing with a culling of 150 works from its collection that date back approximately 2,000 years. Roman portraits, Celtic metalwork, Indian Buddhas and Egyptian sculptures spell ''multiculturalism'' in the Ancient World. Metropolitan Museum. Oct. 3-Jan. 14.

''LOVE AND LOSS: AMERICAN PORTRAIT AND MOURNING MINIATURES'' Often painted in watercolor on thin disks of ivory and enclosed in lockets, these portraits were painted on commission to commemorate births, marriages and deaths by artists famous (John Singleton Copley, Benjamin West) and unknown. The show examines the connections between the miniature and the history of private life in America. Yale University Art Gallery. Oct. 30-Dec. 30. (203-432-0600) www.yale.edu/artgallery.

* ''EDWARD STEICHEN'' A chronological survey, the first in 40 years, of this influential American photographer will include his iconic shots of Manhattan and of luminaries like Greta Garbo and J. P. Morgan, along with examples of his paintings and textile designs. Whitney Museum. Oct. 5-Feb. 4.

''LEE KRASNER'' This retrospective brings Krasner home to the city where she lived and worked. Famously the wife of Jackson Pollock, she was an artist with a mind, a life and a style of her own. Brooklyn Museum. Oct. 6-Jan. 7. A related article is on Page 91.

''SPANISH IMPRESSIONISM AND POST-IMPRESSIONISM: A NEW SELECTION'' The Hispanic Society of America on Manhattan's upper Upper West Side is a gold mine of modern Spanish painting, a tradition that includes such virtuosi as Sorolla and Fortuny. Seldom seen work by both will be brought to light and, as a bonus, there are fabulous Sorolla murals of Spanish village life on permanent view. Hispanic Society of America. Oct. 6-Dec. 22. (212-926-2234) www.hispanicsociety.org.

''RADCLIFFE BAILEY: THE MAGIC CITY'' This Atlanta-based artist combines expressionist painting, photography and sculpture in dense, poetic images of African-American history. Birmingham Museum of Art, Alabama. Oct. 8-Dec. 31. (205-254-2565) www.artsBMA.org.

* ''ART NOUVEAU, 1890-1914'' had its debut at the Victoria and Albert in London and it's a very V & A affair: a vast assemblage of ceramics, jewelry, glass, textiles and furniture, along with paintings and sculptures, all to document the slinky fin-de-siecle Euro-American design movement. The National Gallery is adding a slew of material for its presentation, which is on view from Oct. 8-Jan. 28. The show will move on to the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum April 21-July 8.

* ''ANTIOCH: THE LOST ANCIENT CITY'' This archaeological show brings to light one of the most important cultural centers of the ancient world through frescoes, mosaics, metalwork, glassware and a re-creation of a Roman dining room. Worcester Art Museum in Massachusetts, which organized it. Oct. 8-Feb. 4. (508-799-4406) www.worcesterart.org. Traveling to the Cleveland Museum of Art (March. 19-June 3) and the Baltimore Museum of Art (Aug. 30-Dec. 30).

''WHITFIELD LOVELL: WHISPERS FROM THE WALLS'' This audio-visual installation in the form of a one-room cabin is about the uprooting of an African-American community in the 1920's. The Studio Museum in Harlem. Oct. 11-Dec. 31. (212-864-4500) www.studiomuseuminharlem.org.

''ARCHITECT OF DREAMS: THE THEATRICAL VISION OF JOSEPH URBAN'' The German-born Urban was best known for his architecture -- the New School for Social Research, for example -- but also designed stage sets for the Metropolitan Opera and the Ziegfeld Follies. Watercolor studies and stage models of his theater work will be at the Wallach Art Gallery at Columbia University, which has a strong track record with archival exhibition like this. Oct. 11-Dec. 16. (212-854-7288) www.columbia.edu/cu/wallach.

''POWER AND DESIRE: SOUTH ASIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE SAN DIEGO MUSEUM OF ART, EDWIN BINNEY 3RD COLLECTION'' Painting in India has a long history that survives, in part, in pictures known as miniatures. Whether they come from the court workshops of Rajput princes or from the grand Mughal ateliers in Delhi, they are amazing, and the Binney collection has a full range of styles. Asia Society. Oct. 12-Jan. 7. (212-288-6400) www.asiasociety.org.

''LEONARDO DREW'' A large-scale abstract installation and drawings by a young artist who evokes African-American rural and urban experience in monumental, material-rich sculpture. The Bronx Museum of the Arts. Oct. 5-Mar. 4.

* ''THE GOLDEN DEER OF EURASIA: SCYTHIAN AND SARMATIAN TREASURES FROM THE RUSSIAN STEPPES'' You'll probably be able to see this show glowing on the horizon, what with its two-foot-high sculptures of deer and other gold items brought up from digs in southern Russia. Metropolitan Museum. Oct. 12-Feb. 4. And there's more precious metal in the ''Gold of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures from Ancient Ukraine,'' which lands at the Brooklyn Museum at the same time. Oct. 13-Jan. 21.

* ''UTOPIA: THE SEARCH FOR THE IDEAL SOCIETY'' This collaboration between the New York Public Library and the Bibliotheque National in Paris is about concepts of the ideal society in Western culture from classical antiquity to the present. Voltaire's manuscript of ''Candide'' will be here, along with some Shaker boxes, photographs of a Florida town named Disney's Celebration and a copy of the Declaration of Independence in Thomas Jefferson's hand. New York Public Library. Oct. 14-Jan. 27. (212-869-8089) www.nypl.org.

''PAINTING THE TOWN: CITYSCAPES OF NEW YORK'' A portrait of New York from 1809 to 1997, organized by a museum that specializes in the subject. Museum of the City of New York. Oct. 14-Dec. 31. (212-534-1672) www.mcny.org.

''YES YOKO ONO'' Ms. Ono was one of the early participants in the international Fluxus movement, and this first major United States retrospective will survey her career from the 1960's to the present with films, videos, artist's books, installations and instructional pieces. Organized by Alexandra Munroe and Jon Hendricks for the Japan Society Gallery. Oct. 18-Jan 14. (212-832-1155) www.jpnsoc.org. Traveling to the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis (March 10-June 17); Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston (July 13-Sept. 16); List Visual Arts Center at M.I.T., Cambridge, Mass. (Oct. 18, 2001-Jan. 6, 2002); Art Gallery of Ontario, Toronto (Feb. 22-May 20, 2002); San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (June 22-Sept. 8, 2002) and to Asia.

''GIORGIO ARMANI'' Did the fashion mogul sort of, like, rent the Guggenheim for this ramp-filling survey, or what? With the director-designer Robert Wilson in charge of the installation, Style is the name of the game. Guggenheim Museum. Oct. 20-Jan. 17. Traveling to the Guggenheim Bilbao Mar. 13-Aug. 26.

''THE KOREAN WAR IN AMERICAN ART AND CULTURE'' Scans a historical episode through period artifacts as well as work by contemporary Korean-American artists like Michael Joo, Yong Soon Min and Ik-Joong Kang. Organized by Simon Taylor for the Guild Hall Museum, East Hampton, N.Y. Oct. 21-Jan. 7. (631-324-0806) www.guildhall.org.

''GLENN LIGON'' Mr. Ligon, an artist whose text-based explorations of black life in America were an important part of art in the 1990's, has created new large-scale work for this show at the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis. Oct. 22-March 11.

* ''MADE IN CALIFORNIA: IMAGE AND IDENTITY, 1900-2000'' This broad-spectrum thematic take on a century of art in California is the largest exhibition ever done by a museum noted for its compendious and unorthodox projects, and the results could be absorbing. Work by artists, well known and unknown, will share space with posters, books, advertisements and other evidence of the kind of pop culture California practically invented. Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Oct. 22-Feb. 25.

''NARRATIVES OF AFRICAN AMERICAN ART AND IDENTITY: THE DAVID C. DRISKELL COLLECTION'' The artist and historian David C. Driskell has been collecting since the early 1950's, and a representative selection of his holdings is in this traveling show at the Newark Museum. Oct. 25-Feb. 25. A concurrent show of work by Mr. Driskell is being presented by Aljira, A Center for Contemporary Art at the Paul Robeson Gallery of Rutgers University, Newark. Oct. 25-Dec. 13. (973-643-6877).

''TAINO'' The inauguration of a new permanent gallery dedicated to the art of the Taino, a culture that flourished in the Caribbean islands from 1200 to 1500, represents an important step for El Museo del Barrio, which offered a scholarly exhibition of this still under-studied material in 1997. The new gallery opens on Oct. 26. On the same day, a show of Latin American photography from the collections of the Lehigh University in Pennsylvania also goes on view at the museum. Museo del Barrio. (212-831-7272) www.elmuseo.org.

''WOLFGANG LAIB'' A midcareer retrospective for a sculptor whose spare, meditative work, inspired by Minimalism and non-Western cultures, is made of organic ingredients like pollen, rice and beeswax. Hirshhorn Museum. Oct. 26-Jan 22. Traveling to the Henry Art Gallery, Seattle (Feb. 13-May 6); Dallas Museum of Art (May 29-Sept. 2); Scottsdale Museum of Contemporary Art, Arizona (Oct. 5-Dec. 30); Museum of Contemporary Art, San Diego (Jan. 25-April 21, 2002); Haus der Kunst, Munich (Oct. 8, 2002-Jan. 5, 2003). An installation made of pollen will be at the Berkeley Art Museum in California Oct. 14-Dec. 17.

''BETWEEN THE THUNDER AND THE RAIN: CHINESE PAINTINGS FROM THE OPIUM WAR THROUGH THE CULTURAL REVOLUTION, 1840-1979'' Drawn from a single California private collection, this show highlights work by a wide range of artists during a turbulent period that saw the end of dynastic rule, Japanese occupation and the Cultural Revolution. Asian Art Museum of San Francisco. Oct. 25-Jan 14. (415-379-8800) www.asianart.org.
''NEW WORK: EDUOARD DUVAL CARRIE'' This Haitian-born artist evokes Caribbean religious themes in a site-specific installation at the Miami Art Museum. Oct. 26-Jan. 14.

''ADRIAN PIPER: A RETROSPECTIVE, 1965-2000'' A hard-hitting gathering of text-based photography, installations and early paintings by an American conceptualist who, since the early 1970's, has been one of the most incisive and articulate commentators on the politics of race. Organized by Maurice Berger for the Fine Arts Gallery, University of Maryland, where it opened, it will be at the New Museum of Contemporary Art. Oct. 26-Jan. 21. Traveling to the Weatherspoon Art Gallery, University of North Carolina, Greenboro (Feb. 11-April 15) and the Contemporary Arts Center, Cincinnati (June 23-Aug. 19). A separate survey of Ms. Piper's video work, ''MEDI(t)ATIONS,'' organized by Dara Meyers-Kingsley, will also be at the New Museum and is on view at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles through Nov. 5.
''HENRI MICHAUX'' A survey of calligraphic works on paper by the Belgian poet and critic will be at the Drawing Center in SoHo. Oct. 28-Dec. 20.

''VIK MUNIZ'' The first museum retrospective of the Brazilian-born artist known for his photographic images made with sugar, yarn and chocolate syrup will inaugurate the new Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The show then tours to the Contemporary Art Center, New Orleans, and elsewhere. Also at the Tang: ''S.O.S: The Sound of Art,'' an exhibition of contemporary work composed of or incorporating audio elements, including work by a master of the medium, Stephen Vitiello. Oct. 28-Jan. 31. (518-580-8080) www.skidmore.edu/tang.

''PAUL MCCARTHY'' This first museum retrospective for an influential California artist will include installations, performance videos and drawings, many of them of the hilariously in-your-face, ''parental guidance advised'' variety. Mr. McCarthy is big, bad and major. Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles. Oct. 26-Jan 21. Traveling to the New Museum of Contemporary Art Feb. 15-May 13.
November

''INTERACTIVE DESIGN LAB,'' organized by the artist and writer Ronald Jones, is a sampling of interdisciplinary artists involved in exploring new technologies. Artists Space. Nov. 9-Jan. 31. (212-226-3970) www.artistsspace.org.

''PAINTING ON LIGHT: DRAWING ON STAINED GLASS IN THE AGE OF DURER AND HOLBEIN'' This show, which is on view at the J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles, through Sept. 24, brings together more than 50 stained-glass panels from the Gothic and early Renaissance periods, along with 80 drawings of window designs, many of them by the leading artists of the day. St. Louis Art Museum. Nov. 4-Jan. 7.

''TAOISM AND THE ARTS OF CHINA'' This ambitious exhibition will explore the pervasive relationship between the indigenous philosophy-religion known as Taoism and Chinese art and culture, with examples of sculpture, painting, calligraphy, textiles and books. Art Institute of Chicago. Nov. 4-Jan 7. (312-443-3600) www.artic.edu. Traveling to the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco (Feb. 21-May 13).

''CHORUS OF LIGHT: PHOTOGRAPHS FROM THE SIR ELTON JOHN COLLECTION'' The British pop veteran has amassed a considerable collection of work by blue-chip figures like Berenice Abbott, Tina Modotti and Edward Weston. ''I never get fed up looking at the images,'' says Sir Elton. Nearly 400 pieces will be on view at the High Museum of Art, Atlanta, with ''celebrity portraits'' in a separate show in the museum's downtown gallery. Nov. 4-Jan. 28.

''MIRIAM SCHAPIRO: A RETROSPECTIVE OF PAINTINGS, 1954-1997'' covers the career of an artist who was a central figure in the early feminist art of the 1970's and in the Pattern and Decoration movement. Minnesota Museum of American Art, Minneapolis. Nov. 11-Jan. 28. (651-292-4355) www.mtn.org/mmaa.

ZIMMERLI MUSEUM After being under renovation for more than a year, the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., opens with seven exhibitions highlighting the museum's holdings in Russian 20th-century art and material related to the Japonism movement in America. Nov. 12, various closing dates. (732-932-7237) www-rci.rutgers.edu/zamuseum/.

''BODY POLITICS: THE FEMALE IMAGE IN LUBA ART AND THE SCULPTURE OF ALISON SAAR'' This show includes sculptures from the Luba kingdom of central Africa along with work by the contemporary African-American artist Alison Saar. U.C.L.A. Fowler Museum of Cultural History, Los Angeles. Nov. 12-May 13.

''WORLDS REVEALED: THE DAWN OF JAPANESE AND AMERICAN EXCHANGE'' The Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., is a treasure chest of art and artifacts brought to New England by merchant ships and whalers two centuries ago. This exhibition documents early cultural interactions between the United States and what was once called the Far East. Nov. 17, continuing. Peabody Essex Museum. (800-745-4054) www.pem.org.

''ANDY WARHOL: SOCIAL OBSERVER'' Organized by Jonathan Binstock for the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts (where it is on view through Sept. 21), this show examines the Pop-meister's unblinking view of the social issues of the postwar years, from racial violence to the cult of celebrity. His political views veered between principled concern and opportunism (portrait commissions from the high and mighty were a career priority), but nothing escaped his attention. Corcoran Gallery. Nov. 18-Feb. 19.
December

''LISA YUSKAVAGE'' Ms. Yuskavage's paintings of extravagantly nubile women have attracted a lot of attention in the last few years. Some feminists find them retrograde; others say that they're taking control over what was once the exclusive terrain of ''the male gaze.'' Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia. Dec. 2-Feb. 4. (215-898-7108) www.upenn.edu/ica.

* ''INDIA THROUGH THE LENS: PHOTOGRAPHY 1840-1911'' With formal portraits of dressed-to-the-nines maharajas, scenes of British colonial life joining Felice Beato's documentation of the aftermath of the Indian Mutiny of 1857, this is bound to be a mesmerizing show. Arthur M. Sackler Gallery. Dec. 3-Mar. 25.

''CHARLOTTE SALOMON: LIFE? OR THEATER?'' Salomon died at Auschwitz at age 26 and left behind hundreds of semi-autobiographical paintings on paper that document her haunted life. The show originated in London, is at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, through Oct. 29 and travels to the Jewish Museum Dec. 10-Mar. 25.

''THE DRAFTSMAN'S ART: MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE NATIONAL GALLERY OF SCOTLAND'' Leonardo, Raphael, Rubens, Blake, Ingres, Seurat, with a few guys you've never heard of. Enough said. Frick Collection. Dec. 12-Feb. 25.
January

''ANDY WARHOL: PHOTOGRAPHY'' Warhol, with his infinite capacity for absorbing data, almost always packed a tape recorder or a camera, and sometimes both. This show covers the range of his photographic work. International Center of Photography, New York. Jan. 11-Mar. 18.

''INSIDE SPACE: EXPERIMENTS IN REDEFINING ROOMS'' The first show organized by the M.I.T. List Visual Art Center's new curator, Bill Arning, will see an international group of young artists -- among them Monica Bonvicini, Teresita Fernandez, Juan Maidigan and the team of Elmgreen and Dragset -- shaking up interior architecture. M.I.T. List Visual Arts Center, Cambridge, Mass. Jan. 16-April 8.

'JEAN POYET: ARTIST TO THE COURT OF RENAISSANCE FRANCE'' The illuminator Jean Poyet (active circa 1483-1503) served in the courts of three French kings. His Prayer Book of Anne de Bretagne is a gem of the Morgan Library's collection. This compare-and-contrast look at Poyet in the context of his contemporaries will be at the Morgan Library. Jan 25-May 6.

''GAUGUIN'S 'NIRVANA': PAINTERS AT LE POULDU, 1889-90'' Gauguin spent a brief time in the fishing village of Le Pouldu in Brittany with his disciple, patron and rival, the Dutch artist Jacob Isaac Meyer de Haan, who painted alongside him and paid the bills. Wadsworth Atheneum. Jan. 26-April 29.

* ''ALFRED STIEGLITZ AND MODERN ART IN AMERICA'' A look at Stieglitz's formative role in advancing art in America, as photographer, publisher and gallery director. Works that he showed at his galleries will be reassembled; his 1914 exhibition of African art will be partially reconstructed. There will also be mini-surveys of American artists he championed, among them Charles Demuth, Arthur Dove, Marsden Hartley, Georgia O'Keeffe and Edward Steichen. National Gallery of Art. Jan. 28-April 22.

''ABRAHAM BLOEMAERT (1566-1651) AND HIS TIME'' Bloemaert was a skilled Dutch Mannerist painter of landscapes and religious scenes and apparently an excellent teacher with many talented pupils in Utrecht. This small show centers on a single painting by him in the museum's collection. Museum of Fine Arts, St. Petersburg, Fla. Jan. 28-April 8. (727-896-2667) www.fine.arts.org.

''JANINE ANTONI'' Ms. Antoni was the winner of the 1999 Larry Aldrich Foundation award, and work created during her recent residency at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn., appears there from Jan. 21-May 20. (203-438-4519) www.aldrichart.org.

''EDOUARD MANET: THE STILL-LIFE PAINTINGS'' Manet's late still lifes of flowers in tumblers are among his most purely beautiful pictures. They will be joined in this show, which originated at the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, by earlier paintings and prints. Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. Jan. 28-April 22. (410-547-9000) www.thewalters.org.

''MODERN CHINESE PAINTING, 1840-1980: SELECTIONS FROM THE ROBERT H. ELLSWORTH COLLECTION IN THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART'' Organized by Wen C. Fong, this is a selection from nearly 500 works in the Ellsworth collection, all created during a period of dramatic political change as China entered the modern world. Metropolitan Museum. Jan. 30-Aug. 19.
February

''VAN GOGH AND PAINTERS OF THE PETIT BOULEVARD'' looks at the painter's relationship to artists of the Parisian avant-garde, among them Gauguin, Pissarro, Seurat and Toulouse-Lautrec. St. Louis Art Museum. Feb. 17-May 31.

''DISTANT SHORES: THE ODYSSEY OF ROCKWELL KENT'' A survey of landscape paintings by an American artist and illustrator whose commitment to populist politics was unswerving but whose conservative art fell into disfavor after World War II. Organized by the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., the show appears at the Terra Museum of American Art, Chicago. Feb. 24-May 20. (312-664-3939) www.terramuseum.org.

''ROSMARIE TROCKEL: DRAWINGS'' A show of drawings by this artist caused a stir at the Museum of Modern Art in 1980, and there is reason to have high hopes for this new exhibition, which will be on view at the Pompidou Center in Paris before coming to the Drawing Center in SoHo. Feb. 24-April 7.

''TREASURY OF THE BASEL CATHEDRAL'' More than 70 liturgical items from the Basel Cathedral's treasury, which was dispersed in the 19th century, are reunited. One of the original storage cupboards is on display, too. Metropolitan Museum. Feb. 27-May 27.

''WILLIAM KENTRIDGE'' The animated films -- narratives of political and personal turmoil -- by this South African artist have been a staple of international art festivals. Ten are included here, along with related drawings and prints. The show has its debut at the Hirshhorn Museum, Washington. Feb. 28-May 6. Traveling to the New Museum (June 7-Sept. 16); Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago (Oct. 20-Jan. 20, 2002); the Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston, (Feb.-May 2002); Los Angeles County Museum of Art (June-Sept. 2002).
March

''EGYPTIAN ART FROM THE BRITISH MUSEUM'' The dynastic blowouts in New York and Boston last season left you hungry? There's more of the same in this show drawn from a thoroughbred collection. Organized by the American Federation of Arts, it opens at the Toledo Museum of Art. Mar. 2-May 27. (800-644-6862) www.toledomuseum.org. Traveling to Wonders, Memphis International Cultural Series (July 2-Oct. 21); Brooklyn Museum of Art (Dec. 1, 2001-Feb. 24, 2002); Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City (April 12-July 7, 2002); Minneapolis Institute of Art (Dec. 20, 2002-Mar. 16, 2003); Field Museum, Chicago (April 26-Aug. 3, 2003); Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore (Sept. 5, 2003-Jan. 7, 2004).

''ANDREAS GURSKY'' The curator Peter Galassi is in charge of this show made up of more than three dozen of the German-born artist's panoramic photographs, which turn modern life into a nightmare of material plenitude. Museum of Modern Art. Mar. 4-May 15.

''INTIMATE WORLDS: MASTERPIECES OF INDIAN PAINTING FROM THE ALVIN O. BELLAK COLLECTION'' A superb collection of miniatures that has been promised to the Philadelphia Museum and is on view in its entirety for the first time under the curatorial hand of Darielle Mason. Philadelphia Museum of Art. March 4-April 29. (215-684-8100) www.philamuseum.org.

''AUGUST SANDER: GERMAN PORTRAITS, 1918-1933'' Sander's photographs scrutinized the social soul of a country and an era. The faces of peasants, artists and industrialists fill this survey of pictures made during the post-World War I Weimar Republic up to the eve of Hitler's Third Reich. J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles. Mar. 6-June 24.

''VERMEER AND THE DELFT SCHOOL'' Organized by the Metropolitan Museum and the National Gallery, London, this exhibition perks up the standard image of Delft as a town of hushed Vermeerian interiors by adding busy historical paintings, princely portraits and attention-grabbing decorative arts items. Metropolitan Museum. Mar. 8-May 27.

''GRANDMA MOSES IN THE 21ST CENTURY'' begins with painting from the 1940's by the self-taught upstate New York artist Anna Mary Robertson ''Grandma'' Moses and ends with her last picture, in 1961. Her work was overexposed in the past, but she's really good. National Museum of Women in the Arts, Washington. Mar. 15-June 10. (202-783-5000) www.nmwa.org. Traveling to the San Diego Museum of Art (June 30-Aug. 26); Orlando Museum of Art (Sept. 15-Nov. 11); Brooklyn Museum of Art (Dec. 1-Jan. 27, 2002); Gilcrease Museum of American History and Art, Tulsa (Feb. 23-April 20, 2002); Columbus Museum of Art, Ohio (May 11-July 28, 2002); Portland Art Museum, Oregon (Aug. 17-Dec. 1, 2002).

* ''WILLIAM BLAKE, 1757-1827'' More than 200 works, including one-of-a-kind hand-printed and painted books, by this British poet, political revolutionary and mystic, who saw angels sitting in trees, are in a show organized by the Tate Gallery. Metropolitan Museum. Mar. 27-June 24.

''THE PLEDGE OF FRIENDSHIP: AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHY AND MALE AFFECTION, 1840-1918'' Organized by the art historian David Deitcher, an examination of images of male intimacy as seen in daguerreotypes, tintypes and paper photographs from the 19th and early 20th centuries. Also on view in what sounds like a dynamite lineup: the first museum survey devoted to Kiki Smith's photographs, and a show titled ''Behind Closed Doors: The Art of Hans Bellmer.'' International Center for Photography Midtown. Mar. 29-June 10.
April

''RALPH FASANELLA'S AMERICA'' A retrospective of paintings by the wonderful second generation Italian-American artist who depicted minutely detailed scenes of labor history, American politics and his own urban working-class life. Fenimore Art Museum, Cooperstown, N.Y. April 1-Dec. 31.

''AZTLAN TODAY: THE CHICANO POSTNATION'' Aztlan is the legendary territory, covering parts of both Mesoamerica and the American Southwest, claimed as homeland by the ancient Aztecs and by Mexican-Americans or Chicanos today. This show includes photography and video by a dozen Chicano artists, including Laura Aguilar, Daniel Joseph Martinez and Kathy Vargas. Bronx Museum of the Arts. April 5-Sept. 9. Another show, ''The Road to Aztlan: Art from a Mythic Homeland,'' is a historical investigation of the cultural makeup, ancient and modern, of the region. Los Angeles County Museum of Art. May 13-Aug. 26.

''SANTOS: SCULPTURE BETWEEN HEAVEN AND EARTH'' An exhibition of small carved wooden polychrome religious figures from the collection of El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan. Newark Museum. April 18-July 29.

''MARLENE DUMAS WITH LAYLAH ALI'' Two artists whose very different figurative styles deal indirectly with implied narratives of repression and violence. Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston. April 18-July 1. (617-266-5152) www.icpboston.org. Work by Ms. Ali is also on view at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, San Francisco. Feb. 10-May 6.

''MONDRIAN: THE TRANSATLANTIC PAINTINGS'' is a gathering of 15 paintings that the Dutch artist began in Europe and completed in America after he fled Europe during World War II. Organized in part by Harvard's Straus Center for Conservation, the show offers detailed technical evidence of the revisions the artist made to the original paintings -- a jazz fanatic, he wanted to add what he called ''more boogie-woogie'' -- as well as insights into his technical process. Busch-Reisinger Museum at Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass. April 28-July 22. (617-495-9400) www.artmuseums.harvard.edu.

''L'ESPRIT NOUVEAU: PURISM IN PARIS, 1918-1925'' The classical geometric simplicity and machine aesthetic promoted by the likes of Le Corbusier and Fernand Leger are the focus of this exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. April 29-Aug. 5.

''SPIRIT WORLD: MEDIUMISTIC AND VISIONARY MESSAGES'' is an international show of work by self-taught artists who generated images while in a state of trance, or who chose to experiment with mystic or metaphysical issues. Museum of American Folk Art. April-Sept. (212-977-7170) www.folkartmuseum.org.
May

''JACQUELINE KENNEDY: THE WHITE HOUSE YEARS'' The Inaugural pillbox hat and the red dress she wore for her televised White House tour are among the 80 items associated with America's style-setting First Lady put together for this show by the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum. May 1-July 15.

* ''OVER THE LINE: THE ART AND LIFE OF JACOB LAWRENCE'' This retrospective of around 90 paintings by the esteemed artist who died this June coincides with the publication of a catalogue raisonne of his work. The show is organized by the Phillips Collection, Washington. May 26-Aug. 19. (202-387-2151) www.phillipscollection. org. Traveling to the Whitney Museum (Nov. 8, 2001-Feb. 3, 2002); Detroit Institute of Arts (Feb. 23-May 19, 2002); Los Angeles County Museum (June 16-Sept. 8, 2002); Museum of Fine Arts, Houston (Oct. 6-Jan. 5, 2003). The artist's ''Toussaint L'Ouverture Series'' will be on view at the Norton Museum of Art, West Palm Beach, Fla., Oct. 7-Dec. 3. (561-832-5196) www.norton.org. His two early series of paintings devoted to Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman will be at the Speed Art Museum, Louisville, Ky., Feb. 13-April 22. (502-634-2700). www.speedmuseum.org.
June

''YVES TANGUY'' A centennial birthday retrospective for the French Surrealist artist who painted bad-dream moonscapes running off to the horizon. Menil Collection, Houston. June 1-Sept. 16. (713-525-9400) www.menil.org.

''SNOWDON'' According to the director of the National Portrait Gallery in London, Lord Snowdon, ex-husband of Her Royal Highness Princess Margaret, ''has known everyone worth knowing.'' Here are his pictures of fabulous people -- kings and queens and actors and models -- to prove it. Yale Center for British Art. June 15-Aug. 19. (203-432-2800) www.yale.edu/ycba.

''MARISOL'' A selective survey of some two dozen of this artist's large-scale Pop-inflected figurative sculptures made from carving, constructing, drawing and painting. Organized by Judy Collischan for the Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase, N.Y. June 17-Sept. 2. (914-251-6100) www.neuberger.org.
''MIES IN BERLIN'' includes 30 designs by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe done between 1905 and 1938, the year he emigrated to the United States. Museum of Modern Art. June 21-Sept. 11, 2001).

''WORSHIPPING THE ANCESTORS: RITUAL AND COMMEMORATIVE PORTRAITS IN LATE IMPERIAL CHINA'' In China, ancestors were powerful beings and their portraits were venerated. Three dozen near-life-size examples from the Qing Dynasty (1644-1911) will cast their imperturbable glances around the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery in Washington. June 17-Sept. 9.

''MICHELANGELO DRAWINGS AND OTHER TREASURES FROM THE CASA BUONARROTI, FLORENCE'' will have about two dozen pieces by the man himself, including studies for the Sistine Chapel. High Museum of Art, Atlanta. June 23-Sept. 2.

''H. C. WESTERMANN'' The first career survey for Westermann (1922-1982) since the Whitney's in 1979 includes his kooky, often aggressively pessimistic sculptures and drawings. It begins at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago. June 30-Sept. 23. Traveling to the Hirshhorn in Washington (Feb. 14-May 2, 2002); the Menil Collection, Houston (Oct. 4, 2002-Jan. 5, 2003). A show of the artist's prints will be at the Smart Museum, University of Chicago. June 28-Sept. 9.
Compiled with the assistance of Anna Bahney.
THE ANNOTATED LIST: ART
